DOC.HEAD: Chinese Inflation Down in November; New Loans Made to Industry
DOC.TEXT: Prices in November were only 5.9 percent higher than a year earlier, the government said Sunday in announcing in the lowest inflation rate China has seen since 1987. However, the government was forced again to bail out large state-owned factories hard hit by the austerity program that has reduced inflation. The official China Daily said the People's Bank of China, the central bank, granted the equivalent of $638 million in loans last week to the state sector, which the government says must be preserved as a pillar of the socialist system despite its inefficiencies. Similar loans totalling $1.9 billion were reported in October and November. The China Daily said the People's Bank and other banks anticipate making total emergency loans of $21.2 billion to state-owned industries in the fourth quarter to keep production from sliding further. Industrial production dropped 2.1 percent in October from October 1988, its first decline in a decade, and in November was up less than 1 percent over November 1988. Some economists have pointed to the sluggish industrial performance as a sign that the economy has entered a recession. The government clamped down on official spending, new construction and bank loans in September 1988 in an effort to cut inflation that peaked at about 40 percent, China's highest rate since the Communists took power in 1949. Since then, inflation has dropped sharply, and the China Daily said vegetable prices in October were actually 4.6 percent lower than in October 1988, while fruit prices also declined. However, the austerity policy has left many companies so short of cash that they cannot purchase raw materials, forcing the government to issue special loans to aid priority sectors such as the large state factories. The austerity also has resulted in a backlog of unsold consumer goods, including automobiles and television sets, which were in high demand last year. When foreign joint-venture car makers, including Shanghai Volkswagen and Guangzhou Peugeot, appealed for help, the government spent $94 million to buy 7,440 cars. The state also issued emergency loans to grain bureaus so they could purchase the fall harvest. The repeated emergency loans have dealt a blow to the government's plan to balance its budget. Earlier this year the government projected a $2.2 billion deficit, but Western economists say it could be four times that much. They say the government's method of controlling inflation, by clamping down on credit, has only propelled the economy toward a recession without resolving the causes of inflation, such as the irrational price structure. The official Xinhua News Agency, which reported the November inflation figure, said retail sales dropped by 1 percent from the previous November. Bank savings were up more than 25 percent from January, to $106.8 billion.
